dspace-development.title: DataSpace error logging is filling the inbox of the dspadmin [at] e-mail account

comments.body:
The following errors are still being e-mailed approximately every 7 minutes:

```bash
An internal server error occurred on https://dataspace.princeton.edu:

Date:       10/27/21 10:54 PM
Session ID: 3577FC8C6611C43DE13A7BEE8CD84534
User:       Anonymous
IP address: 10.246.0.2

-- URL Was: https://dataspace.princeton.edu/bitstream/88435/dsp01nz8062179/6/RecallFiles_published.tgz
-- Method: GET
-- Parameters were:


Exception:
javax.servlet.ServletException: java.lang.IllegalStateException: Cannot forward after response has been committed
```

https://git.atmire.com/clients/princeton-5/-/merge_requests/new?utf8=%E2%9C%93&merge_request%5Bsource_project_id%5D=788&merge_request%5Bsource_branch%5D=hotfix-10-27-21-dataspace-prod&merge_request%5Btarget_project_id%5D=788&merge_request%5Btarget_branch%5D=dataspace-prod may provide a remedy for this, and I have deployed this into the production environment.
This has not been effective, and I must apply an explicit rule to block this IP address within the Apache2 proxy configuration.

```
<Proxy *>
    Order allow,deny
    Deny from 10.246.0.2
    Allow from all
  </Proxy>
```

Was necessary in order to ensure that the offending IP address is no longer able to access the DataSpace servlet applications.

The IP-address range-based filtering was *not* successful, however, the following was:

```
SetEnvIfNoCase User-Agent "(SemrushBot|DataForSeoBot|Bytespider)" bad_user_agent
  <Proxy *>
    Order allow,deny
    Allow from all
    Deny from env=bad_user_agent
  </Proxy>
```

In addition to this, it does *not* appear that NGINX is used at all for the DataSpace production server (modifying the configuration files for this, as well as stopping this, seemed to have no effect).

In spite of the severe increase in traffic from a Facebook crawler, I am going to attempt to permit access from these given what I have found in similar cases (please see an example at https://blog.paranoidpenguin.net/2020/10/a-denial-of-service-attack-from-facebook/).

dspace-development.title: Generate a report for Senior Theses Collections

comments.body:
Attempting to use `rspec` in order to implement test suites for https://github.com/pulibrary/dspace-cli has resulted in inconsistent failures which I do not have time to immediately address, but they typically require manually stubbing Java package imports for JRuby:

```ruby
1) DSpace::CLI::Query #parent accesses any existing parent query node
     Failure/Error: let(:described_class) { DSpace::CLI::Query }

     NameError:
       missing class name (`org.dspace.content.Item')
```

Which I have attempted to override with approaches such as:

https://github.com/pulibrary/dspace-cli/blob/issues-503-jrgriffiniii-theses-report/spec/dspace/cli/query_spec.rb#L62

comments.body: Does this need a `@type` property? @eliotjordan any idea what that should be?
That definitely needs a type. Let me take a look at notes from the Geo Predicates Working Group.

There's a couple of ways to go about this, but what I discovered is that most of most that document is not valid JSON-LD. only a few properties are correctly displayed (it's long because the context URI couldn't be de-referenced and I had to paste in the whole context). 

Is the point here to get rid of the unnecessary fields (id, internal_resource, etc...) so it is indexed correctly in DPUL?

The recommended predicates in this case are:

http://www.w3.org/2003/01/geo/wgs84_pos#lat
http://www.w3.org/2003/01/geo/wgs84_pos#lon

GeoJSON coordinates could also be used.

Could we flatten this out and add `latitude` and `longitude` properties to the document instead of `coverage_point`?

**Example**

Add to context:
```
    "wgs84": "http://www.w3.org/2003/01/geo/wgs84_pos#",
    "latitude": {
      "@id": "wgs84:lat"
    },
    "longitude": {
      "@id": "wgs84:lon"
    },
```

Add to document:
```
  "latitude": 40.34907855,
  "longitude": -74.66020631
```

Even better idea (maybe); add a generic GeoJSON geometry property to our JSON-LD documents. Can be used for more than just CoveragePoint:

Context becomes:

```
  "@context": [
      "https://bibdata.princeton.edu/context.json",
      "https://geojson.org/geojson-ld/geojson-context.jsonld"
    ]
```

Add to document:

```
  "geometry": {
    "type": "Point",
    "coordinates": [-74.66020631, 40.34907855]
  }
```

orangelight.title: Display issue references and coin references in the orangelight record page.
Search results API calls to bibdata vs SRU

comments.body:
Notes on my little dive into Alma SRU and our Availability API needs.

* The data from the SRU comes in XML, there is no option to fetch JSON.
* Whereas the API fields come in “human readable” form (e.g. title, author, place of publication) the fields in SRU are straight MARC fields (245bc, 776a, 264abc) when using the default `marcxml` format or any of the other MARC schemas. 
  * It is possible to request other record schemas (e.g. DC, MODS) that provide non-MARC fields but each of them is different. We’ll need to review what works best for us. 
  * Because the format is different from the API results, switching from the API to SRU will require some code changes to map to the new field names. 
  * However, since we only use availability data and not bib record descriptive data (title, author, etc) this might not be a problem.
* The availability information (AVA and AVE fields) that comes in the SRU response is almost identical to what we get from the API. There is one little extra value (subfield u) in the API compared to what we get in the SRU, not sure if this will be significant for us :
```
<subfield code="u">publishing_base_url undefined?u.ignore_date_coverage=true&rft.mms_id=99124374163506421</subfield>
```

Here is an example of the data that we get for record [99124374163506421](https://catalog.princeton.edu/catalog/99124374163506421) in both formats

* [API response](https://gist.github.com/hectorcorrea/8f441f48fc406f193619fb1ee7e326bb#file-99124374163506421_api-json)
* API - [the XML in the JSON anies field expanded](https://gist.github.com/hectorcorrea/8f441f48fc406f193619fb1ee7e326bb#file-99124374163506421_api_anies-xml)
* [SRU response in XML](https://gist.github.com/hectorcorrea/8f441f48fc406f193619fb1ee7e326bb#file-99124374163506421_sru-xml)

It’s not clear to me that the SRU calls are faster (or slower) than the response times that we get from the API. A few sample tests gave response times around 2 seconds when querying batches of 10 MMS_IDs. As with the Alma API data seems to be cached so repeating a query gives faster response times.

Here is  a sample query to fetch 10 records at once via SRU: 

```
curl https://princeton.alma.exlibrisgroup.com/view/sru/01PRI_INST?version=1.2&operation=searchRetrieve&recordSchema=marcxml&query=alma.mms_id=99112014383506421+or+alma.mms_id=99112014753506421+or+alma.mms_id=99112015033506421+or+alma.mms_id=99118724103506421+or+alma.mms_id=99125186219506421+or+alma.mms_id=99113684863506421+or+alma.mms_id=99121938583506421+or+alma.mms_id=99121389713506421+or+alma.mms_id=99125347328506421+or+alma.mms_id=99125136623506421
```

# In conclusion
I am not sure this is worth implementing. 

The only advantage that I see is that we could replace the calls to bibdata to calls straight to Alma (i.e. no PUL middle tier) since there is no API key needed when making the calls. But this is not something that we need or were after.

Some of the disadvantages are:
* We don’t gain much/anything in performance. 
* It will require parsing XML responses either in Ruby in bibdata or in Javascript in Orangelight.
* The names of the fields are straight from MARC (this could be a problem if we want combined values in the title, author, or place of publication)
